characters: THE FAR END OF THE BARRACK
BARBED WIRE AGAINST A WINTRY NIGHT SKY

dialogues.speaker: BARBED WIRE AGAINST A WINTRY NIGHT SKY
dialogues.text: Beyond it, more barbed wire. Ice has formed on the strand Now and then searchlight beams crisscross the pattern. As the CAMERA SLOWLY MOVES along the double fence, SUPERIMPO

dialogues.speaker: THE GREAT CAMP
dialogues.text: A wide expanse of barren ground checkered with clusters o barracks, sectioned off into compounds by double barbed-w fences, nine feet high. Searchlights sweep over the barra the muddy ground with the snow patches, and the pine fore beyond the barbed-wire. The searchlights come from the go towers -- little guard houses elevated on poles --  interspersed along the fences.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with an occasional  stammer) I don't know about you, but it always  make me sore when I see those war  pictures -- all about flying leather- necks and submarine patrols and  frogmen and guerillas in the  Philippines. I don't want to take  anything away from those guys, but  what gets me is that there never was  a movie about P.O.W.s -- about  prisoners of war. Now my name is  Clarence Harvey Cook, -- they call  me Cookie. I was shot down over  Magdeburg, Germany back in 43. That's  why I stammer a little once in a  while, especially when I get excited  and I always get excited when I talk  about Stalag 17. I spent two and a  half years in Stalag 17. Stalag is  the Kraut word for prison camp and  number 17 was somewhere near Krems  on the Danube. There were about forty  thousand P.O.W.s there, if...

dialogues.speaker: OUR COMPOUND
dialogues.text: In the foreground the big gate. Above it a sign: STALAG 1 D. On both sides of the gate German guards in heavy coats rifles slung over their shoulders. They stomp about in  enormous boots with high cork soles to keep warm. Beyond gate about eight low barracks form a U about the Appell- ground. They are primitive one-story wooden structures al set up on stilts about two feet high. From one of the  buildings -- the Administration Building -- flies the  swastika. In between the barracks are the wash latrines. road runs through the slushy compound to the compound bey

dialogues.speaker: ONE OF THE GOON TOWERS
dialogues.text: A couple of German guards up there, one at the machine gu the other working the searchlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: you bothered to count the Russians  and the Poles and the Czechs. In our  Compound there were about six hundred  and thirty of us -- all American  airmen, all shot down by the Krauts --  radio operators, gunners and engineers --  all sergeants. Now you put six hundred  and thirty sergeants together and  boinnnnng! -- you've got yourself a  situation! There was more fireworks  shooting off around that place! Take  for instance the story about the spy  we had in our barrack. It was about  a week before Christmas in '44 and  two of our guys -- Manfredi and  Johnson to be exact -- were just  getting set to blow the joint...

dialogues.speaker: THE HUNDEFUEHRER
dialogues.text: A German guard plodding along inside the barbed wire with four mean mastiffs straining at the leash. The light from the goon tower grazes over him.

dialogues.speaker: ONE OF THE BARRACKS
dialogues.text: The light sweeps slowly over the long shack. Catches the  sign: BARACKE 4. Catches one of the doors, locked from ou with a heavy wooden bar.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE BARRACK
dialogues.text: Bunks on both sides. Tripledecked bunks. In the bunks sev five American P.O.W.s huddled in blankets. In between the bunks, in the little space left to them, crude tables, an iron stove, makeshift stools. Every inch crowded with wha they have. Up above and all the way down the barrack hang their wash. Over all of it, the heavy stench of seventy-f men cooped up. From outside through the broken, patched  windows the searchlight sweeps over the bunks. The men ar all asleep. Or are they?

dialogues.speaker: THE FAR END OF THE BARRACK
dialogues.text: This is the strategic spot of the story. In the five tier of bunks live our major characters. In the upper bunk lies HOFFY. Little fellow. Plenty of  authority. The Barrack Chief. His eyes are wide open. He studying his wristwatch, the phosphorescent numerals shin in the dark. In the other bunks lie the others, wide awake, tense: DUKE, big bellyacher. TRIZ, six-foot-three, ninety-eight pounds. PRICE, the barrack Security Chief. Quiet, touch of class. MANFREDI, no cover, fully dressed. HARRY, bug-eyed, cocky. BLONDIE, fair-skinned, boyish. JOHNSON, fully dressed like Manfredi. Scared. SEFTON, casual. In his mouth a cold cigar butt. Hoffy again. Still staring at the wristwatch. This is the moment. He lifts the metal dogtags off his chest and jigg them. This is the signal. Duke instantly slides out of the bunk, grabs up his blank and moves toward the window. A searchlight beam sweeps ac Duke goes flush on the ground. The light passes on. Duke  gets up again and starts hanging the blanket over the win Now the others go into action, silently, efficiently. Exc for Manfredi and Johnson they are all in long winter  underwear, some in slacks and socks. As for Sefton, he is lying in his bunk just watching them Blondie hangs a blanket over the window. Triz swings one  over the clothesline to shield off their end of the barra Hoffy and Price light a couple of handmade lamps: margari in tin cans with the wick stuck inside. Manfredi and Johnson are putting on their leather jackets Harry tries to awaken STOSH in the bunk above him. The wo boards around Stosh's bunk are plastered with Betty Grabl cheesecake. Harry pokes him. Stosh does not respond. Harr interlocks his fingers, puts them close to Stosh's ears a cracks them in a SHARP SALVO. Stosh opens his eyes, dazed Harry pats Stosh's cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a whisper) Get up, Animal! Betty Grable's on  the phone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stosh gives him a dirty look. Gets out of the bunk. He an Harry move to the little iron stove. Triz is already  dismantling the pipe above the stove. Harry and Stosh lif the stove and start inching it to one side. Hoffy moving to a large bucket of water. It is a trick jo a bucket within a bucket. He lifts out the shallow inner  part with the water. Hidden underneath are some civilian  clothes. He takes them out, crosses to Manfredi and Johns (All the dialogue in this scene in whispers, of course.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's your civilian clothes, boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Hoffy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duke takes the clothes from Hoffy and starts stuffing the into a small barrack bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bury your Army outfits before you  get out of the forest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The compass is the top button on  your pants, Johnson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sefton, propped up in his bunk, watches the proceedings w a pitying little smile. He eyes wander to Harry and Stosh By now they have moved the stove some four feet to the si and start carefully lifting some sawed-off planks out of floor. Blondie is standing watch by the blanket-covered window,  peeking out. Price slips a wire hook down into the crack between a bun and the wall, fishes out a sheaf of papers and walks to  Manfredi and Johnson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anybody asks for your papers, you're  French laborers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands them the papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your map -- your Kraut money -- Swiss  francs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, let's hear it once more, boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been over it a hundred times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's hear it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We stick to the forest going west  until we hit the Danube --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then follow the Danube up to Linz --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Linz we hop a barge and go all  the way to Ulm --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From OFF come the WEIRD SOUNDS of an ocarina being played They turn. It's JOEY in his bunk playing the sweet potato. He's nuts all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it, Joey -- go to sleep!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey hides the ocarina behind his back, afraid they may t it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Johnson) Go on. You're in Ulm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once in Ulm we lie low until night,  then take a train to Friedrichshafen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then once in Friedrichshafen we steal  a rowboat, get some fishing tackle,  and start drifting across the lake --  always south -- until we hit the  other side -- Switzerland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sefton has gotten out of his bunk, and is picking up the  margarine lamp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bingo. Once in Switzerland, just  give out with a big yodel so we'll  know you're there. It's a breeze,  boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lights his cigar butt with the margarine lamp. Manfred and Johnson shoot him a nervous glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay out of it, Sefton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just one question. Did you calculate  the risk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry and Stosh have by now removed the loose planks off floor. A small black hole gapes below them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hoffy, Price, Manfredi and Johnson move toward the trap d Johnson carrying the barrack bag. Hoffy looks at his watc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got ten minutes to get through  the tunnel. That'll bring you out  just when the Jerries are changing  shifts. (Turns to window) Blondie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blondie gives him the high sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Manfredi and  Johnson) Okay, boys -- peel off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are handshakes, goodbyes and good-lucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you get going on those broads,  think of me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Animal! Animal! Aren't you ashamed  of yourself? A couple of guys are  trying to escape and you're thinking  of broads. Broads?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He does a take.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with feeling) We'll miss you, you cruds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and climbs down through the trap. Before Manfred follows him, he turns away, goes down on his knee, crosse himself quickly.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERNEATH BARRACK 4
dialogues.text: Johnson has already landed on the ground. Manfredi slips  down. They look around and start crawling off in the dire of the latrine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stosh is peering after them, his head hanging down throug the trap from above. Beyond him in the barrack, Hoffy, Pr and Duke bend over Stosh, waiting for developments.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERNEATH BARRACK 4
dialogues.text: From Stosh's point of view: Manfredi and Johnson have now reached the end of the barrack and are crawling into the  compound towards the wash latrine some fifteen feet away. searchlight sweeps dangerously towards them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stosh pulls up from the trap, his eyes closed, his finger in his ears. He doesn't want to see or hear the two out t get shot. The others stand petrified. No shots, no scream So Stosh bends down into the trap again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manfredi and Johnson just manage to fling themselves back under the barrack as the searchlight sweeps past. Then, t get on their feet again and dash to the wash latrine -- j ahead of another searchlight from the other direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A primitive, roofless structure, with wooden partitions  shielding it from the outside. Above, a water tank with p running down to spigots over a trough. Under the trough, wooden lattice to stand on. Manfredi and Johnson have reached first base. They stand  breathless. Then Manfredi picks up the lattice, leans it  against the trough, and lifts a dirt-covered trap leading into the tunnel. Johnson has tied the barrack bag to his ankle. They HEAR BARKING. Freeze.

dialogues.speaker: THE HUNDEFUEHRER
dialogues.text: Leading the mastiffs past the wash latrine. One of the  mastiffs is BARKING. He seems to smell something, but the other dogs pull him along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manfredi and Johnson wait until the BARKING fades in the  distance. Johnson, the barrack bag tied to his ankle, jum down into the narrow vertical shaft. Manfredi follows. He pulls the trap shut over his head in such a way that the  lattice falls into place on top of it.

dialogues.speaker: THE TUNNEL
dialogues.text: A shaft about three feet square and five feet deep leads  into a narrow, crudely shored-up tunnel. Johnson and Manf light their Zippo lighters and start worming their way th the tunnel, Johnson leading the way, the barrack bag drag from his ankle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry and Stosh moving the stove back into place. Hoffy f up the trick bucket. Price pacing up and down. Sefton lea against a bunk, smoking the cigar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ought to be under the barbed  wire soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still covering the  window) Looks good outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope they hit the Danube before  dawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They got a good chance. This is the  longest night of the year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet you they make it to  Friedrichshafen all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet they get all the way to  Switzerland!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I bet they don't even get out of  the forest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all look at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now what kind of a crack is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No crack. Two packs of cigarettes  say they don't get out of the forest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's enough, Sefton. Crawl back  into your sack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'd make book on his own mother  getting hit by a truck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sefton takes two packs of cigarettes from his pocket and  throws them on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anybody call?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, Sefton -- butt out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute, Hoffy -- I want to  back those kids. I'll cover ten of  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts shaking cigarettes out of his pack onto the tab

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put me down for ten, you louse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (throwing two packs  on the table) I'll call the whole pot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever you say. (calling off) Hey, Cookie -- get me some more  cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COOKIE, a chipmunk of a kid, scrambles down from his bunk the one above Sefton's. Drags out a footlocker from under Sefton's bunk. The footlocker is chained to the bunk-post Cookie opens it, starts taking cigarettes out. About twelve guys are around Sefton by now, making their  bets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's two and a half.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No butts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cookie comes over with a carton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (With a stammer) W-w-will that do or do you want some  m-m-m --?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That'll do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rips open the carton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speak up, boys. Any more sports in  the crowd?

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE TUNNEL
dialogues.text: Johnson and Manfredi crawling on, by the light of their  Zippos. Johnson dragging the bag behind him. They are dri with perspiration. From above comes a little shower of lo earth. Johnson stops as he comes to the end of the tunnel. There another shaft leading up. He picks up a rusty can and sta digging at the earth above.

dialogues.speaker: THE OPEN GROUND ABOVE
dialogues.text: In the pine forest some thirty feet outside the barbed wi From the goon towers, the lights sweep over the camp and  over the edge of the forest. The tin can thrusts through the ground as Johnson digs in the open. Then, when the opening is wide enough, he climb out, his face covered with sweat and dirt. He helps Manfr out. They lie on the ground for a moment, exhausted. Then Johnson starts untieing the bag from his ankle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rises. There is a SHARP BURST of MACHINE GUN FIRE. Man falls instantly. Johnson, not knowing where the gunfire i coming from, tries to turn and run, the bag dragging behi him. From a hillock about thirty feet off a MACHINE GUN, manne by three German guards, is blasting away. A light from one of the goon towers picks up Johnson, run The machine gun gets him, ripping his chest. He spins and crumples to the ground. The light swings to Manfredi.  Bleeding, he tries to crawl back to the safety of the tun There is another BURST of FIRE --

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE BARRACK
dialogues.text: The men have all run to the window and look out. All except Sefton and Cookie. They stand at the table whe the cigarettes are. And in back of them: Joey, sitting in his bunk, comprehending nothing. There is another BURST of FIRE. Then all is silent. The m turn back into the room, sickened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Filthy Krauts!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What slipped up, Hoffy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't ask me. Price was elected  Security.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Price) Okay, Security -- what happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I knew. We had everything  figured out. To the last detail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe the Krauts knew about that  tunnel all the time!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, Animal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe they were layin' for 'em out  there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (casually) Yeah. Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives Cookie a sign. Cookie pulls the front of his shi out of his pants and holds it out against the edge of the table. Sefton sweeps the mass of cigarettes into Cookie's shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold it, Sefton. So we heard some  shots -- so who says they didn't get  away?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anybody here wanna double their bet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer. He nods to Cookie again. Cookie carries the  cigarettes to their bunks. Sefton follows him, kicks open the footlocker. Cookie dumps the loot in. The men are looking at them. Stosh sees a cigarette on th floor which Cookie has dropped. He picks it up and tosses into Sefton's footlocker viciously.

dialogues.speaker: THE CAMP
dialogues.text: Another miserable day has begun. The barracks loom in the murky light. From the Administration Building -- the one with the swas come a dozen German guards, Lugers hanging from their bel They spread out and cross the muddy compound toward the  barracks, BLOWING WHISTLES shrilly. They lift the wooden  bars off the doors and go inside. FELDWEBEL SCHULZ has arrived at Barrack 4. He is an enorm man, about fifty-five. His cauliflower ears make a good  vegetable for his pig-knuckle face. He removes the bar, o the door, stands there WHISTLING like a madman, enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funny thing about those Krauts. They  hated the sight of us yet they  couldn't wait to look at us again.  Every morning -- at six on the dot --  they'd have the Appell -- that's  roll call to you. Each barrack had  its own alarm clock. Our alarm clock  was Johann Sebastian Schulz. I  understand the Krauts had a composer  way back with the Johann Sebastian  in it -- but I can tell you one thing:  Schulz was no composer. He was a  Schweinehund. Oh, Mother -- was he  ever a lousy Schweinehund!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schulz is marching down the barrack, beating the bunks wi his stick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aufstehen, gentlemen! Appell! Raus!  Hurry up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men start sliding out of their bunks. Others roll over in their sacks, groaning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must get up for roll call! Raus,  raus, gentlemen! Everybody aufstehen!  Raus!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We heard you, Schulz! And good morning to you! Aw, break it off! Why don't you take that whistle and  shove it! Tell the Kommandant I've got  dysentery!  Shut up, Schulz -- you're talking to  sergeants of the United States Air  Force!  Look at this chilblain. Ain't it a  beaut!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raus! Raus! Aufstehen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whacking the bunks, Schulz has reached our end of barrack Hoffy and Price are getting into their clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, sack rats -- cut the bitchin'  and get up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duke, Triz and Blondie start climbing out, yawning and  scratching themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, Schulz -- you guys had machine  gun practice last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (throwing up his hands) Ach, terrible! Such foolish boys.  Such nice boys. I'd better not talk  about it. It makes me sick to my  stomach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You killed them, huh? Both of them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Such nice boys! It makes me sick to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't wear it out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schulz moves to Joey. Joey is sitting in his bunk, TOOTLI on his ocarina. Schulz raps the sweet potato with his sti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside! You, too! Put away the  piccolo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey hides the sweet potato, staring at Schulz, frightene Schulz jerks him off the bunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Los, los. Dummkopf!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pushing in) Lay off, Schulz. He's got a sickness.  He's krank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes I think he is fooling us  with that crazy business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? How would you like to see the  guts of nine pals splattered all  over your plane? (to Joey) C'mon Joey -- don't be afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He helps him up and starts putting clothes on him. Schultz has approached bunk with Harry and Stosh. He poke Harry with the stick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aufstehen, gentlemen! Please! You do  not want to stay in bed on such a  beautiful morning we are having today!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, Schulz --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jawohl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sprechen Sie deutsch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jawohl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then droppen Sie dead!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (splitting his sides) Ja -- ja! Droppen Sie dead! Always  mit the jokes! Droppen Sie dead!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pokes Stosh with the stick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aufstehen! Appell!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves on. Harry bends over Stosh, shaking him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get up, Animal. Come on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stosh doesn't budge. Harry again gives him a knuckle-crac salvo. Stosh opens his eyes automatically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sweetly) Good morning, Animal! What'll it be  for breakfast? Scrambled eggs with  little sausages? Bacon and eggs sunny- side up? Griddle cakes? A waffle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it, Harry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffee? Milk? Or how about a little  cocoa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grabbing him by the  collar) Why do you do this to me every  morning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with sadistic speed) Hamburger and onions! Strawberry  shortcake! Gefillte fish! Banana  split! French fried potatoes! Chicken  a la king!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last items are coming out with a gurgling SOUND as St tightens the grip on Harry's neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll kill you, Harry -- so help me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let go, Animal! It's roll call! Hitler  wants to see you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sefton is standing near his bunk, getting dressed. Cookie helping him to zip up his luxurious flyer's boots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Sefton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Schulz. And how's Mrs.  Schulz? And all the little Schulzes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine -- fine!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at the two bunks which were occupied by Manfredi and Johnson. Takes off his gloves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let us see. We have now two empty  bunks here. (takes out pencil and  notebook, writes) Nummer einundsiebzig und Nummer  dreiundsiebzig in Baracke vier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suppose you let those mattresses  cool off a little -- just out of  decency?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ja, ja, gewiss! It is only that we  are cramped for space with new  prisoners every day. (to the whole barrack) Gentlemen! Outside! Please! Do you  want me to have trouble with the  Kommandant again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts herding them out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Schulz -- as long as you're  going to move somebody in -- how  about a couple of those Russian  broads?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russian women prisoners?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jawohl!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some are not bad at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just get us a couple with big  Glockenspiels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ja! Ja! Droppen Sie dead!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Splitting his sides, he pushes them out, and follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most of the P.O.W.s are out of their barracks by now. A m of freezing, disheveled men. Some wear Army coats over th underwear, knitted caps pulled down over their ears. Some are huddled in blankets, their feet in wooden clogs. Only few are fully dressed and shaven. A few are on crutches o bandaged up. They assemble before their respective barracks, forming a facing the center of the compound. The barrack chiefs are assisting the guards in lining them up, fifteen abreast a five deep. Supervised by Schulz and Hoffy the last ones from Barrack emerge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, men -- fall in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From off comes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ach-tung! Abzaehlen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The HUB-BUB dies down. The guards march down the front line of their barrack gro counting the lines of five in German. As Schulz passes him, Blondie spots something in the midd of the compound. He nudges Duke. Duke nudges Price, Price Harry, Harry Stosh, Stosh Cookie. Cookie nudges Sefton wh is putting on his wool gloves. The glove drops. They all  look off in the same direction. In the center of the compound, right smack in the mud, li the corpses of Johnson and Manfredi, covered with a blank You know it's them because Johnson's foot is sticking out with the barrack bag still tied to it. A stir goes through the men of Barrack 4. They are hit ha All but Sefton. He looks at the corpses for a moment, the bends down, picks up the glove and starts putting it on. In front of the Administration Building a German Lieutena has been supervising a couple of guards as they lay narro planks over the mud in a line leading to the middle of th compound. He turns now to the P.O.W.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parade Atten-tion!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The German guards come to rigid attention. The Americans  just stand there, sullenly. The Lieutenant comes to a heil salute. Through the open d of the Administration Building steps the Kommandant, OBER VON SCHERBACH, followed by another Lieutenant. Von Scherb is a big erect officer of the Potsdam School. Over his  shoulder hangs a furlined officer's coat. His boots shine like polished glass. He glances over the compound, then w down the planks, followed by the two Lieutenants, marchin through the mud on both sides of him. Von Scherbach stops the end of the plank. In front of him lies a deep puddle. clicks his heels and raises his hand in a heil salute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guten Morgen, Sergeants!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A glowering silence from the men. Von Scherbach lowers hi hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nasty weather we're having, eh? And  I so much hoped that we could give  you a white Christmas -- just like  the ones you used to know... Aren't  those the words that clever little  man wrote -- you know the one who  stole his name from our capital --  that something-or-other Berlin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waits until his nasty little joke sinks in. Schulz has come up to the Lieutenant, salutes and hands him the slip of paper with the prisoner count.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at that mud. Come spring -- and  I do hope you'll still be with us  next spring -- we shall plant some  grass here -- and perhaps some  daffodils --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to the Lieutenant for the tabulations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ich bitte!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checking the papers) Melde gehorchsamst: 628 Gefangene.  Zwei Mann fehlen in Baracke vier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the P.O.W.s) I understand we are minus two men  this morning. I am surprised at you,  gentlemen. Here I am trying to be  your friend and you do these  embarrassing things to me. Don't you  know this could get me into hot water  with the High Command? They do not  like men escaping from Stalag 17 -  especially, not enemy airmen from  Compound D. We plucked you out of  the skies and now we must see to it  you do not fly away. Because you  would come back and blast our cities  again. The High Command would be  very angry with me. They would strip  me of my rank. They would courtmartial  me, after all these years of a perfect  record! Now you wouldn't want that  to happen to me, would you?  Fortunately, those two men --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the ranks of the men comes the EERIE DISSONANT SOUND of Joey's SWEET POTATO. Joey, in the second row of the Barrack 4 company, is play on his ocarina, oblivious to what is going on. Stosh turn and quickly grabs the ocarina from Joey's mouth. Von Scherbach chooses to disregard the little musical  interlude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As I was saying: fortunately those  two men did not get very far. They  had the good sense to rejoin us again,  so my record would stand unblemished.  Nobody has ever escaped from Stalag  17. Not alive, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He snaps his fingers in the direction of the guard who st watch over the corpses. The guard pulls back the blanket in such a manner that al we can see is the barrack bag tied to Johnson's leg. The P.O.W.s however see the corpses. There is an ANGRY BU Hoffy marches up to Von Scherbach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (saluting) Sergeant Hoffman from Barrack 4.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Sergeant Hoffman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the duly elected Compound Chief,  I protest the way these bodies are  left lying in the mud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. According to the Geneva  Convention, dead prisoners are to be  given a decent burial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. I'm aware of the Geneva  Convention. They will be given the  burial they deserve. Or perhaps you  would suggest we haul in twenty-one  cannons from the Eastern Front and  give them a twenty-one gun salute?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hoffy turns on his heel and walks back to his men. Von Scherbach, without even looking at the corpses, snaps his fingers. The guard throws the blanket back over the  bodies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the last time, gentlemen, let me  remind you: any prisoners found  outside the barracks after lights  out will be shot on sight.  Furthermore, the iron stove in Barrack  4, the one camouflaging the trap  door, will be removed. And so that  the men from this barrack will not  suffer from the cold, they will keep  warm by filling in the escape tunnel.  Is that clear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men just stand there, in frustrated anger. Stosh clen the ocarina in his first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, then, gentlemen. We are  all friends again. And with Christmas  coming on, I have a special treat  for you. I'll have you all deloused  for the holidays. And I'll have a  little tree for every barrack. You  will like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stosh, with a quick underhand flip, throws the sweet pota in the direction of Von Scherbach. It lands smack in the middle of the puddle in front of Vo Scherbach and splashes his boots with mud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stiffening) Who did this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolute silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will give the funny man exactly  five seconds to step forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks about the compound. Five seconds pass. Nobody mo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you shall all stand here if it  takes all day and all night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the ranks of the men of Barrack 4, Stosh steps forwa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is better!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But his triumph is short-lived, for almost instantly Harr steps forward alongside Stosh. Then Duke and Blondie and  Cookie. Spontaneously, men from all the other barracks fo until all the P.O.W.s have moved forward one step.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see! Six hundred funny men! ...There  will be no Christmas trees! But there  will be delousing. (to Schulz) With ice water from the hoses!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wheels about and marches back up the plank and into th Administration Building. His Lieutenants after him. Two o the guards start picking up the planks again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting, to the  P.O.W.s) Dismissed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men break ranks, going off in all directions, some ba to the barracks, some toward the latrines. Only Joey stands where he stood, his eyes fastened on the puddle. Slowly he walks toward it. He bends down and fish out his sweet potato, dripping with mud. It is broken. He wipes the pieces off on his coat and hides them inside hi jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Packed with men from Barrack 4, about two dozen of them.  Others waiting outside for their turn. At the trough wash Hoffy, Price, Duke, Stosh, Harry, Cookie and Sefton. No s A couple of worn-out towels. Except for Sefton: He's got  soap, towel and tooth brush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (imitating von  Scherbach) 'We will remove the iron stove --  the one that was camouflaging the  trap door.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm telling you, Animal, these Nazis  ain't Kosher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can say that again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm telling you, Animal -- these  Nazis ain't Ko --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grabbing him) I said say it again. I didn't say  repeat it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Triz reaches for Sefton's soap, but gets a sharp rap on t knuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Private property, bub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come the Krauts knew about that  stove, Security? And the tunnel? How  come you can't lay down a belch around  here without them knowing it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look -- if you don't like the way  I'm handling this job --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kill it, Duke. It's got us all  spinning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want to know what makes those  Krauts so smart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe they're doin' it with radar.  Maybe they got a mike hidden some  place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Right up Joey's ocarina.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or maybe it's not that they're so  smart. Maybe it's that we're so  stupid. Maybe there's somebody in  our barracks that's tipping 'em off!  One of us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You betcha. I said one of us is a  stoolie. A dirty, stinkin' stoolie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that Einstein's theory? Or did  you figure it out yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A P.O.W. sticks his head into the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (breathless) New dames in the Russian compound!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stosh lets go with a SCREAM. He takes off like shot from cannon, Harry after him. Instantly the wash latrine is em of the men, wet as they are. Nobody is left but Price, Ho Duke, Sefton and Cookie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a stampede. P.O.W.s are rushing across the compound  toward the Russian compound. Stosh, charging like a bull, gets tripped and falls flat his puss right into a mud puddle. Harry zooms past him. S picks himself up and runs after him, his winter underwear dripping with mud.

dialogues.speaker: THE BARBED WIRE FENCE
dialogues.text: dividing the American and Russian compounds. P.O.W.s rush from all sides, about a hundred of them. They go as far a they are permitted; to a low warning wire, running parall to the big fence some fifteen feet away. To cross the war wire is verboten. The German guards up in the goon towers insure that. There is great excitement among the P.O.W.s. Some give ou with cat-calls and wolf-whistles; others just stand there staring. Beyond the fence a new batch of Russian prisoners has jus been brought in. German guards are counting some sixty  prisoners, about twenty of them women. They all are in  uniforms and wear boots, a bedraggled lot. The women are buxom dames, not exactly Golden Circle material, but this war. The Americans jump up and down trying to attract the wome attention. They throw cigarettes, chewing gum, chocolate. One guy is dancing the Kazatski, two of his pals holding up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yee-ow! Tovarich! Tovarich! Oh you sweethearts! Let's open the third front! Hey, Minks -- Pinsk! How about some borscht -- the two of  us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stosh and Harry push right up to trip wire. Stosh, plaste with mud, goes completely berserk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey -- Russki -- Russki! Look at  those bublichkis! Over here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Comrade! Comrade! Otchi Tchorniya --  Otchi Tchorniya!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stosh puts two fingers in his mouth and tries to whistle. gets his mouth full of mud. Spits out the mud. Searches m through his pockets and throws whatever he can find acros the fence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chewing gum -- chewing gum!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of the Russian women break the ranks to pick up the  goodies that come flying over. The German guards push the back. The women smile at the Americans and wave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at the top of his  lungs) Look at me! I'm your baby! (to Harry) Get a load of that blonde one! Built  like a brick Kremlin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey -- Comrade! Over here! This is  Harry Shapiro -- the Volga Boatman  of Barrack four!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lay off! The blonde is mine!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The women are being led away by the guards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screaming) Hey, Olga -- Volga -- wait for me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes off blindly toward the women, trips immediately  over the warning wire and falls flat on his face in the m again. Up in the goon tower the guard swivels the machine gun an yells down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zurueck oder wir schiessen! Zurueck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry frantically grabs Stosh by the feet and pulls him b under the wire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me go! Let me go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll shoot you, Animal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lies right on top of him, holding him by the wrists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care! Let me go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From OFF come the SOUNDS of a dishpan being beaten and sh of "Chow!" Some of the P.O.W.s start to go back to the  barracks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's chow, Animal! Chow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who wants to eat? I just wanna get  over there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No you don't! You don't want any  broads with boots on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care if they wear galoshes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want Betty Grable!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling) Betty Grable!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stosh's face lights up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Animal! When the war's over, remember  I told you I'd fix you up with Betty  Grable!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? How you going to fix me up  with Betty Grable?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How? We go to California. I got a  cousin that's working for the Los  Angeles Gas Company. That's how we  get the address, see? Isn't that  clever? I take you up to her house  and ring the doorbell and say,  'Congratulations, Miss Grable. We  have voted you the girl we'd most  like to be behind barbed wire with,  and I'm here to present the award'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the award?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What d'ya think, jerko! You're the  award!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me? What if she don't want me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If she don't want you, she don't get  anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grabbing him) You're teasing me again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gagging) Let go, Animal! It's chow! We'll  miss chow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stosh relaxes his hold and drops him like a limp rag. The scramble to their feet and run off towards Barrack 4.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chow time. Most of the men sit around eating. Only a few still in line. They stand before a washtub, from which Tr ladles out a thin brew. Then each man gets a pitiful slic of sawdust bread, cut by Blondie at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in chow line) What's this stuff anyhow? Manicure  water?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is what I like -- a hearty meal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They finally found the formula: an  Ersatz of an Ersatz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hoffy, back in the line with Joey, carrying both chow can

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's holding up the parade?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you supposed to drink this stuff  or shave?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (next in line) Drink. (tastes the stuff) Shave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hoffy gets the two cans filled, gives one to Joey. This i the end of the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone else want potato soup?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer. He takes out a homemade washboard and a pair o socks, puts them in the tea and starts scrubbing. Through the door, Stosh and Harry come running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (out of breath) Chow! Where's the chow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He dashes to his bunk, gets his chow can and is about to it into the tub, when he sees what Triz is doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take your socks outa my breakfast!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Triz takes the socks out. Stosh dips in his chow can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Animal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Your eyeball goes. The top of  your head. Gotta wind up with  athlete's stomach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stosh pours back his tea, a miserable man. His eyes fall the door. An electric shock goes through him. He grabs Ha arm. They look off: Sefton has come into the barrack and is crossing toward t iron stove. In his hand is the incredible -- more beautif than all the Kohinoors in the world: an egg. Harry and Stosh stand there with their eyes bulging. They start forward, drawn by the egg. Cookie is at the stove, tending a can of boiling water. H sees Sefton and puts a makeshift skillet (the banged-up t of a tin can) with a dab of margarine in it, on the fire. Sefton takes some keys out of his pocket, tosses them to  Cookie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Set 'er up, Cookie. I'm starved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cookie goes towards Sefton's bunk. Sefton cracks the egg  into the skillet. Stosh and Harry move in, their eyes bul at sight of the sizzling beauty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy, Animal! Easy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd that come from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a chicken, bug-wit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A chicken?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you remember, Animal? A chicken  lays those things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's beautiful! (to Sefton) You goin' to eat it all yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. The yellow and the white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He flips the egg over in the skillet. Harry and Stosh cov their eyes and yelp in panic. To their relief they see th the egg has landed safely. The aroma of the frying egg ha brought about six P.O.W.s down from their bunks. They cro around, their mouths watering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it all right if we smell it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just don't drool on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going to eat the eggshells?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tosses him the eggshells. Harry gives one half to Stos

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grateful) Thanks. You're a real pal! (on second thought) What're we goin' to do with it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plant it, Animal, and grow us a  chicken for Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cookie, at Sefton's bunk, has taken from one of the  footlockers three cans, a china cup with a broken handle, fork, a spoon, and a salt-and-pepper shaker. He slams the locker shut with his foot and sets everything up on the o footlocker. Hoffy, Duke and Price, seated at the table ea chow, eye him with disgust. From the stove comes Sefton carrying the skillet and the of boiling water. The other P.O.W.s, including Harry and  Stosh, follow him, hypnotized by the egg. Sefton walks to his bunk, sits down on a little stool, puts salt and pepp on the egg. Cookie meanwhile has opened the cans. From on of them he measures out a spoonful of instant coffee into the cup and pours the boiling water over it. Sefton takes two lumps of sugar out of the other can and some Zwieback from the third can. The guys around him sniff the royal  breakfast. The situation is tense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I were you, Sefton, I'd eat that  egg some place else. Like for instance  under the barrack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sipping the coffee,  to Cookie) A little weak today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cookie puts another half a spoonful of instant coffee int the cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Trader Horn! Let's hear it:  what'd you give the Krauts for that  egg?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eating away) Forty-five cigarettes. The price has  gone up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That wouldn't be the cigarettes you  took us for last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was I going to do with them? I  only smoke cigars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice guy! The Krauts shoot Manfredi  and Johnson last night and today  he's out trading with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, this may be my last hot  breakfast on account of they're going  to take away that stove. So will you  let me eat it in peace?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't that too bad! Tomorrow he'll  have to suck a raw egg!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He don't have to worry. He'll trade  the Krauts for a six-burner gas range.  Maybe a deep freeze too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your beef, boys? So I'm  trading. Everybody here is trading.  Only maybe I trade a little sharper.  So that makes me a collaborator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot sharper, Sefton! I'd like to  have some of that loot you got in  those footlockers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You would, would you? Listen, Stupe --  the first week I was in this joint  somebody stole my Red Cross package,  my blanket and my left shoe. Well, I  wised up since. This ain't no  Salvation Army -- this is everybody  for himself. Dog eat dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You stink, Sefton!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come off it! Both of you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple of P.O.W.s hold Duke back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you've done it. You've given me  nervous indigestion. (he gets up) Anything else bothering you, boys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just one little thing. How come you  were so sure Manfredi and Johnson  wouldn't get out of the forest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't so sure. I just liked the  odds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up the skillet with the half-eaten egg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what's that crack supposed to  mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're lying dead in the mud out  there and I'm trying to find out how  come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you how come. (pointing at Hoffy) The Barrack Chief gave them the green  light. And you, our Security Officer,  said it'd be safe. That's how come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crosses to Joey who has been sitting on the edge of th bunk looking on blankly and puts the skillet with the egg his lap. Turns back to the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you guys trying to prove  anyway? Cutting trap doors! Digging  tunnels! You know what the chances  are to get out of here? And let's  say you do get all the way to  Switzerland! Or say to the States?  So what? They ship you to the Pacific  and slap you in another plane. And  you get shot down again and you wind  up in a Japanese prison camp. That's  if you're lucky! Well, I'm no escape  artist! You can be the heroes, the  boys with the fruit salad on your  chest. Me -- I'm staying put. And  I'm going to make myself as  comfortable as I can. And if it takes  a little trading with the enemy to  get me some food or a better mattress  or a woman -- that's okay by Sefton!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He strikes a match on the sleeve of Duke's leather jacket and lights himself a cigar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why you crud! This war's going to be  over some day -- then what do you  think we'll do to Kraut-kissers like  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lunges forward and there is a fracas, the others tryin to hold them back. From off comes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At ease! At ease!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARKO, the Inter-barrack Communications officer, has ente from the compound, followed by a one-legged P.O.W., THE  CRUTCH. Marko gets up on a stool a piece of paper in his  hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling) AT EASE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Break it off, boys! At ease for the  news!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ruckus subsides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today's Camp News! (reading) Father Murray announces that due to  local regulations the Christmas  midnight Mass will be held at seven  in the morning!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can tell Father Murray to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At ease! He also says, quote: All  you sack rats better show up for the  services and no bull from anybody.  Unquote. At ease! Monday afternoon a  sailboat race will be held at the  cesspool. See Oscar Rudolph of Barrack  7 if you want to enter a yacht. Next:  Jack Cushingham and Larry Blake will  play Frank deNotta and Mike Cohen  for the pinochle championship of the  camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a fix.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At ease! Tuesday afternoon at two  o'clock all men from Texas will meet  behind the north latrine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boos and cheers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At ease! Next: A warning from  Kommandant von Scherbach. Anybody  found throwing rocks at low-flying  German aircraft will be thrown in  the boob. At ease! At ease! (then in a lower voice) Are the doors covered?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks around to make sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to The Crutch) Okay, Steve. Give 'em the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Crutch, leaning against the edge of the table, pulls the empty pant leg. Attached there is a small radio, a  makeshift set with tubes showing. Also a pair of earphone Blondie starts getting it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Hoffy) You can keep it for two days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two days? We're supposed to have it  for a week!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're lucky to get it at all. The  boys are afraid the Jerries'll find  it here. This barrack is jinxed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. We'll take care of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Stosh and Harry) Take some men and get the antenna  going. Let's see if we can catch the  BBC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the background, Harry gets a volley ball from under th bunk, Stosh picks up a roll of chicken wire from a corner the barrack, and the two lead six other P.O.W.s out into compound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about those guys last night?  What gives in this barrack anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a little sickness. Somebody  around here's got the German measles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He oughta know. He went to Johns  Hopkins. He used to be a bedpan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the gag?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (imitating him) At ease! At ease!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marko shrugs and turns to Hoffy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be sure to put down the news. Looks  like the Germans have started a  counter-offensive and the other  barracks want to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marko and The Crutch go off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men are setting up the chicken wire, attaching one en to the barrack, and the other to a tall post: it becomes volley ball net, and in turn, an antenna. Stosh is slippi a wire through the window into the barrack. They divide i two teams, Stosh and Harry on opposite sides, and start  playing volley ball. In the background, Marko and The Cru are seen walking away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Triz has connected the antenna wire to the radio on the t able. Blondie is sitting there with the earphones on, wor the dials, Price sitting next to him with pencil and pape The others stand around waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getting anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getting too much. I'm tryin' to  unscramble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you can't get the BBC, how about  getting Guy Lombardo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we boring you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold it... Quiet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He repeats what he hears over the earphones while Price w it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...has driven across Luxemburg...  The second German wedge is reported  fourteen miles west of Malmedy where  tank columns cut the road to  Bastogne... the Allied Air Force is  grounded by poor visibility...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys don't like what they hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The volley ball game is in fine progress, the ball poppin back and forth across the antenna. A German guard approac puzzled over the sports activity on this lousy winter day He is a singularly grim fellow. He starts circling them.  Harry and Stosh, to appear nonchalant, break into the  SCHNITZELBANK SONG. The guard moves dangerously close to window. Quickly Harry flips the ball over the net at him. The guard slaps it back across the net. Again Harry pops at him ... and slowly the guard finds himself sucked into the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wunderbar! Isn't he wunderbar!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's the grrrrreatest!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guard permits himself a smile as he goes on playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys around the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Repeating what he  hears) ...five Panzer divisions and nine  infantry divisions of von Rundstedt's  army have poured into the wide  breach... meanwhile two of Patton's  tank units have been diverted toward  Bastogne and are trying to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's jammed again. Blondie fiddles with the dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Static!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Static is right! The radio's static,  Patton's static, we're static!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it's going to be a longer war  than you figured -- eh, Duke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Triz, who has been standing watch at the door, now sees:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marching toward Barrack 4 are four German soldiers headed Schulz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Triz reaches up and snaps a string. All the wash in the  barrack jumps up and down. That's the signal. Immediately the boys jump into action. Triz and Blondie  disconnect the wires. Hoffy takes the radio off the table and they all start dispersing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schulz and the four German soldiers are about to enter th barrack. Schulz pauses as he sees the guard playing volle ball enthusiastically. Schulz taps him on his back. The g wheels around, freezes, clicks his heels. Schulz gives hi disapproving look. Then he leads the four soldiers into t barrack. Harry, Stosh and the other P.O.W.s follow, worri Schulz and the soldiers enter the barrack, followed by Ha Stosh and the other players. The guys have just assumed innocent positions. A little t innocent maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I interrupt something, gentlemen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. We were just passing out guns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) Always joking. Always making  wisecrackers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wisecrackers? Where did he pick up  his English? In a pretzel factory?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You always think I am a square. I  have been to America. (he shows them his  cauliflower ears) I wrestled in Milwaukee and St. Louis  and Cincinnati. And I will go back!  The way the war is going I will be  there before you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should live so long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schulz has taken a wallet out of his pocket, shows a  photograph to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is me in Cincinnati.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's the other wrestler? The one  with the mustache?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is my wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking the photograph) Look at all that meat. Isn't she the  bitter end!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snatching it from  him) Give it back. You must not arouse  yourselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Schulz! I got a deal for you.  Suppose you help us escape. We'll go  home and have everything ready for  you in Madison Square Garden. For  the world championship! Schulz, the  Beast of Bavaria versus Halitosis  Jones!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Droppen Sie dead! (to the German soldiers) Raus mit dem Ofen. Los! Los!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soldiers move toward the stove. As the scene proceeds they dismantle the stove and ultimately carry it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the P.O.W.s) All right, gentlemen! We will now  all go outside for a little gymnastic  and take some shovels and undig the  tunnel which you digged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't we just plug up that tunnel --  with the Kommandant on one end and  you on the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is not me. It is the orders. I am  your friend. I am your best friend  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut out the guff, Schulz. We're on  to you. You know everything that's  happening in this barrack. Who's  tipping you off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tipping me off? I do not understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're wasting your time, Duke. (to the others) Outside, everybody! Let's get it  over with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a second, Hoffy. Schulz says  he's our best friend. Maybe he can  give us a little hint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Schulz! Spill it! How did  you get the information? About  Manfredi and Johnson? About the stove  and the tunnel? Who's giving it to  you? Which one of us is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which one of you is what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which one of us is the informer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are trying to say that an American  would inform on other Americans?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the general idea. (looking at Sefton) Only it's not so general as far as  I'm concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are talking crazy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking the cigar out  of his mouth) No use, Schulz. You might as well  come clean. Why don't you just tell  'em it's me. Because I'm really the  illegitimate son of Hitler. And after  the Germans win the war you'll make  me the Gauleiter of Zinzinnati.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You Americans! You are the craziest  people! That's why I like you! I  wish I could invite you all to my  house for a nice German Christmas!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Stosh) Why don't we accept, Animal? The  worst that can happen is we wind up  a couple of lamp shades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (jovially) Raus! Raus! All of you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By this time most of them have put on their warm clothes, caps and gloves and are filing out. Schulz starts to follow them, but stops short as he sees: The electric light bulb hanging by a wire from the ceilin Just the bulb. No shade. The wire is tied up into a slip  knot. Schulz reacts to what he has seen. he watches the last of the P.O.W.s leave, and the Germans carry the stove out of the barrack. He closes the door. His entire attitude has  changed. He is serious and efficient. He walks over to th chess set on the table. Out of his pocket he takes a ches piece -- a black queen -- and exchanges it with the black queen from the set. He puts it in his pocket. Steps over the light bulb, pulls the slip knot free and exits. The light bulb hangs straight now, swaying gently in the  empty barrack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men from Barrack 4 are lined up between the latrine a the barbed wire, starting to dig up the tunnel. They are  supervised by German guards. In the background, Schulz is crossing from the barrack towards the Administration Buil As the men dig, they look off at:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was the Beast of Bavaria all right,  as we pieced it together later. And  there was a stoolie in our barrack,  just as Duke said. They had a very  simple communications system -- Schulz  and the stoolie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An open German half-truck driving toward the big gate,  carrying two crude wooden coffins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's how the Krauts knew about the  tunnel, from the day we started  digging. Those poor suckers Manfredi  and Johnson! They got out of Stalag  17 sure enough, only not quite the  way they wanted to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men have stopped digging. As the CAMERA goes down the row they take off their caps. Joey does not comprehend.  Blondie, standing next to him, takes the cap off for him. The CAMERA PULLS PAST Cookie who has taken his cap off, a now STOPS on Sefton. He has seen the coffins. He has seen the others take off their caps. He takes the cigar out of his mouth, snuffs it out, puts it into his pocket, and sl pulls off his cap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As for the stoolie, I just wish he  had German measles because when you  get the measles you break out all  over in red spots, and we could have  pegged him easy. As it was it could  have been anybody in our outfit --  Duke or Hoffy or Price or Goofy Joey  or Harry or the Animal or maybe  Sefton. Sergeant J.J. Sefton. I guess  it's about time I told you a few  more things about that Sefton guy.  If I was anything of a writer I'd  send it in to the Reader's Digest  for one of those 'Most Unforgettable  Characters You've Ever Met'...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A circle about 15 feet in diameter is drawn on the barren ground with white lime. Around it, some forty G.I.s. In t center, Cookie, holding a cardboard box. To one side, sta on a wooden crate, Sefton. In front of him, a makeshift  bookie's desk, a heap of loose cigarettes on top. G.I.s a crowding around, making wagers in cigarettes. Hanging off one side of the desk, the odds board: NO. HORSE ODDS 1.  Whirlaway 3:1 2. Seabiscuit 5:1 3. Equipoise 1:1 4. Twent Grand 4:1 5. Schnickelfritz 10:1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...he was a B.T.O., Sefton was. A  Big Time Operator. Always hustling,  always scrounging. Take for instance  the horse races. Every Saturday and  Sunday he would put on horse races.  He was the sole owner and operator  of the Stalag 17 Turf Club. He was  the Presiding Steward, the Chief  Handicapper, the Starter, the Judge,  the Breeder and his own bookie. He  was the whole works, except that I  was the stable boy for ten smokes a  day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Step up, boys! The horses are at the  post!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five on Equipoise! Give me Equipoise -- ten on the nose! Two on Twenty Grand! Schnickelfritz for me. Five smackers! Equipoise -- one solid pack!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (an unkempt bum) Five on Seabiscuit! Pay you when the  Red Cross parcels come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No credit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a heart, Sefton!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. It's against the rules of the  Racing Commission. (calling out) Already? Any more bets? Shake 'em  up, Cookie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cookie shakes the cardboard box, puts it face down on the ground in the center of the circle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let 'er go! They're off and running  at Stalag 17!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cookie has lifted the box. There are five mice of various colors with numbers 1 to 5 attached to their backs. The m start spreading hesitantly in all directions. The P.O.W.s YELL and SCREAM, rooting for their horses to  reach the circle line first. Among the P.O.W.s Stosh and Harry. Stosh, with a bundle o mutuel tickets in his hand, screaming his head off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Equipoise! Oh, you beauty! This way!  This way!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Equipoise, No. 3, pulls in front and is only a few feet f the edge of the circle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Equipoise! Equipoise! What did I  tell you, Animal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, baby! Daddy's going to buy  you a hunk of cheese!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Equipoise, now only a foot from the finish line, suddenly stops and goes into a dizzy spin. The other mice gain rap

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Straighten out, you dog! This way!  That's no horse -- that's a dervish!  Please! This way! Come to Daddy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a turmoil of SCREAMING G.I.s, Schnickelfritz passes  Equipoise, still spinning like a top, and crosses the lin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The winner is No. 5: Schnickelfritz!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stosh grabs Harry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schnickelfritz! I told you  Schnickelfritz! Why'd you make me  bet on Equipoise!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I clocked him this morning. He was  running like a doll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (choking him) You clocked him! Why don't I clock  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out) The next race will be a claiming  race for four months old and upward  which have not won since November  17th.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While Sefton pays off the winners, Cookie puts up a new o board. New bettors start lining up on the other side. Amo them, Harry and Stosh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a good thing nobody ever asked  for a saliva test. Because I wouldn't  have put it past Sefton to stiff a  horse once in a while -- especially  when the betting was heavy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Near Sefton's bunk, the distillery is set up: a Rube Gold contraption of old tin cans and a maze of piping, a marga lamp burning under the boiler. The whole thing SPUTTERS a HISSES. Behind a makeshift wooden shelf -- the bar -- stands Cook pouring drinks for some eight customers, among them Harry and Stosh, crocked. In Stosh's hand is the big Betty Grab cheese-cake photo from his bunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another one of his enterprises was  the distillery. Believe it or not,  he ran a bar right in our barrack,  selling Schnapps at two cigarettes a  shot. The boys called it the  Flamethrower, but it wasn't really  that bad. We brewed it out of old  potato peels and once in a while a  couple of strings off the Red Cross  parcels, to give it a little flavor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a crying jag) It's not fair, Harry. I'm telling  you, it's not fair! She's been married  for over a year! My Betty! She had a  baby! Didn't you hear it on the radio!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, Animal! Pull yourself together! (off) Hey, Cookie! Belt us again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes their little condensed milk cans, serving as  jiggers, across the bar, counts out four cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at her! Isn't she beautiful!  Married an orchestra leader!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what? There's other women!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for me! Betty! Betty!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut it out. Animal! I'll fix you up  with a couple of those Russian women!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastically) You'll fix me up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, Animal! I'll get you over there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How? Pinky Miller from Barrack 8  tried to get over there and they  shot him in the leg!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It takes a gimmick, Animal, and I  figured us a little gimmick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tapping his forehead) Sharp. Sometimes I'm so sharp it's  frightening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cookie slides over the two tin jiggers. Harry picks them hands one to Stosh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (toasting) To the Brick Kremlin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his eyes on the  cheesecake photo) She'll never forgive me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bombs away!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both drink it down in one gulp, Harry holding his no It's terrible stuff and hits them hard. Stosh goes into a violent fit of coughing, pulling his barrack cap down ove his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Cookie) What are you serving today? Nitric  acid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only work here. Talk to the  Management.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points to Sefton, who is taking inventory of the cigar in his footlocker: cartons, packages, loose ones. He is  tabulating the amounts on a piece of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Management. What are you  trying to do? Embalm us while we're  alive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly what did you expect for two  cigarettes? Eight year old Bottled- In-Bond? All the house guarantees is  that you don't go blind. (to Cookie) Don't ever serve 'em again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blind! Harry! Harry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He staggers around, not realizing his cap is pulled down  over his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry -- I'm blind!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pushing up his cap) Blind? How stupid can you get, Animal?  I drank the stuff myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly he seems not to see too well himself. He gropes  around in panic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Animal! Animal! Where are you, Animal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A big telescope, about seven feet long, is set up on a tr at the window pointing toward the Russian Compound. The  telescope is made of various-sized cans soldered together It's run by Cookie, behind a table, piled with cigarettes and chocolate bars. Bent down peering through the telesco panning it slowly, is a P.O.W. Across the barrack stretch a long line of impatient customers, all the way to the op door and out of it. Cookie taps the peeker to indicate hi time is up. The next in line pays his cigarette and peeks

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The killer-diller, of course -- the  real bonanza -- was when Sefton put  up the Observatory. He scrounged  himself some high-powered Kraut lenses  and a magnifying mirror and got Ronnie  Bigelow from Barrack 2 to put the  whole shebang together for a pound  of coffee. On a clear day you could  have seen the Swiss Alps, only who  wanted to see the Swiss Alps? It was  about a mile away, that Russian  delousing shack, but we were right  on top of it. It cost you a cigarette  or a half bar of chocolate a peek.  You couldn't catch much through that  steam, but believe you me, after two  years in that camp just the idea  what was behind that steam sure  spruced up your voltage.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSIAN DELOUSING SHACK
dialogues.text: About a dozen Russian women, wrapped only in blankets, wa in line. The telescope pans across a couple of windows. T are completely steamed-up by the disinfecting vapors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
