dialogues.text: The P.O.W. is glued to the telescope. Cookie taps him on shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go! Thirty seconds to a  customer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without moving his eye from the telescope, the P.O.W. fis another cigarette from his pocket and gives it to Cookie. Sefton stands at the open barrack door, a cold cigar in h mouth. He surveys the landoffice business, both inside an out, for beyond him a line of about forty more P.O.W.s  stretches into the compound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from rear of line) Hey, Sefton -- what's snarling up  the traffic? By the time we get to  look they'll be old hags!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simmer down, boys. There'll be a  second show when they put the next  batch through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hoffy, Price and Duke come in from the compound. Hoffy ca the situation and pulls Sefton to the side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the big idea, Sefton? Take  that telescope out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Says who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Says me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You take it out. Only you're going  to have a riot on your hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every time the men get Red Cross  packages you have to think up an  angle to rob them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the Krauts find that gadget  they'll throw us all in the boob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They know about that gadget. I'd  worry more about the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose they also know about your  distillery and the horseraces?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just what makes you and them Krauts  so buddy-buddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask Security. (to Price) You tell him, Price. You've got me  shadowed every minute of the day. Or  haven't you found out yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Answer the question. How do you rate  all those privileges?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I grease the Kraut guards. With ten  percent of the take.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And maybe a little something else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little something what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He strikes a match on Duke's dogtag and lights his cigar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lunging at him) Maybe a little information!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hoffy and Price hold back Duke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Break it off!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much more do we have to take  from him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There'll be no vigilante stuff. Not  while I'm Barrack Chief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the window come excited shouts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, look at them!  It's Harry and the Animal!  Look what they're doing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody in the barrack is dashing toward the window giv out on the Russian Compound. Hoffy, Price, Duke, and Seft follow after. The window is packed by G.I.s staring out. More crowding

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those crazy jerks!  They won't get away with it!  The Krauts will shoot them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Harry's little gimmick: He and Stosh are painting white line down the middle of the road leading towards th Russian Compound. Stosh carries the bucket and Harry, mov backwards, wields the brush. They are very close now to t barbed wire fence dividing the compounds. A bespectacled  German guard is standing in front of his sentinel house. They crouch as low as they can as they paint themselves  through the gate past the guard and up the road toward th Russian delousing shack. The guard gives them a glance. I looks okay to him. He starts stamping about at the open g

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: G.I.s at the window, watching in great excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're past the fifty yard line!  Quarterback sneak!  Look at them go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in chorus) We want a touchdown! We want a  touchdown! We want a touchdown!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those idiots! They'll paint themselves  into their graves!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry and Stosh are doing dandy as they paint up the high Harry gets his bearings: the delousing shack is some twen five feet off the road. He paints a very elegant turn off the highway.

dialogues.speaker: THE GATE BETWEEN THE COMPOUNDS
dialogues.text: The German guard is stamping up and down. Suddenly he doe double take as he sees:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The white line leading down the middle of the highway vee off idiotically over the terrain towards the shack.

dialogues.speaker: THE GERMAN GUARD
dialogues.text: He stands there perplexed, then takes off after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry and Stosh have now painted up to the window of the  shack. Without even stopping, they paint right up the wal and around the window. As they paint, they peer in throug the thick steam (through which we cannot distinguish  anything). Now, they paint down the building on the other side of the window and toward the doorway. Into their pat come the boots of the German guard. They paint right over the boots. Then they see the butt of the guard's rifle. T look at each other. They are in trouble. They stop painti and straighten up slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was ist denn hier los? Sie sind  verhaftet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry gives the guard's eye-glasses a couple of quick str of paint. Dropping paint and brush, Stosh and he run like mad back toward the gate. The guard stands there struggling with his glasses. The Russian women, huddled in blankets, giggle their head off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About twenty P.O.W.s lazing about. The sack rats in their bunks. Triz and Price playing chess, Joey looking on blan Sefton, a towel around his neck, is sitting in a chair be shaved by Cookie. Stosh, in his bunk, is carving a new oc for Joey out of wood. CAMERA MOVES SLOWLY to: The electric light bulb, hanging straight and innocent on its wire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now let me see, what came next? Oh,  yes. Next came those new prisoners.  'Twas two days before Christmas when  all through the camp, not a creature  was stirring, not even that lamp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At ease! At ease!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marko, carrying a handful of letters and a book, has ente followed by The Crutch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mail call!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole barrack springs to life, everyone moving toward Marko with whistles, screams and hoorays. Joey, who keeps staring at the chess board. Sefton and Cookie go on with shave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At ease! At ease! First, the  Kommandant is sending every barrack  a little Christmas present. A copy  of Mein Kampf. In the words of Oberst  von Scherbach: 'Now that a German  victory is in sight, all American  prisoners are to be indoctrinated  with the teachings of der Fuehrer.  Unquote. In my own words: (he lets go with a  belch) Unquote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tosses the book into the air. Duke catches it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the wrong direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He flings it at Sefton. It sails past Sefton's head. Cookie ducks. Sefton doesn't even bat an eyelash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must have been some tail gunner! (to Cookie) Go ahead, Cookie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, let's get that mail. Anything  for Stanislaus Kuzawa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At ease! At ease!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Marko calls out the names he hands out the letters. So of the men open them immediately. Others go to their bunk to read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin. Shapiro. Price. Trzcinski.  McKay. Shapiro. Shapiro. Manfredi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is an awkward pause, then Marko puts Manfredi's let in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shapiro. Musgrove. McKay. Peterson.  Cook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cookie comes up for his letter. So do Duke and Blondie. ( names are Musgrove and Peterson.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pirelli. Coleman. Agnew. Shapiro.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a little voice) Nothing for Kuzawa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shapiro. Shapiro.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Harry) Just what makes you so popular?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fanning the letters) Frightening, isn't it? Fifty million  guys floating around back home and  all those dames want is Sugar-lips  Shapiro.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McKay, Agnew. Here, Stosh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds out a letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (revitalized) Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give this to Joey, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marko has now distributed all the letters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At ease! At ease! Here's a little  something from Father Murray. One to  each barrack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has knelt down in front of The Crutch and pulls out fr the empty pant's leg a little Christmas tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he says he wants you cruds to  cut out all swearing during Yuletide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd he get those trees?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Prayed, I guess. They  grew out of his mattress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marko sticks the tree into one of the margarine cans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'll we use for decorations?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For that you got to pray yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes, followed by The Crutch. Stosh sits next to Joey at the table, reading his letter him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: '...and we do hope that you will  finish that last year of law school  when you come back home...' (looks up at Joey) Law school?! You don't want to be a  stinking lawyer with a stinking brief  case in a stinking office, do you,  Joey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey just sits there. Stosh goes on reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: '...And do keep writing, son. Your  letters are very dear to us. With  all our love, Dad.' Here, Joey, take  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's from your Dad, Joey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shoves the letter into Joey's pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next time we write to your folks,  Joey, you know what you're going to  say? You're going to say you don't  want to be a lawyer any more. You  want to be a musician -- like play  the flute, maybe -- eh, Joey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a fleeting smile on Joey's face. Triz, in his bunk, a crumpled letter in his hand, is mumb to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe it! I believe it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You believe what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife. (Reading) 'Darling, you won't believe it, but  I found the most adorable baby on  our doorstep and I have decided to  keep it for our own. Now, you won't  believe it, but it's got exactly my  eyes and nose...' Why does she always  say I won't believe it? I believe  it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blondie is reading his letter, several G.I.s around him,  among them Duke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is from my mother. (he reads) 'I saw a wonderful article on German  prison camps in one of the magazines.  They showed pictures of the tennis  courts and they also say that in the  winter they freeze them over so you  boys can ice skate...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything about us grouse hunting in  the Vienna woods?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continues to read) '...In a way I'm glad you're not in  America right now -- with everything  rationed here, like gas and meat.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heart-rendering, ain't it? Why don't  we send them some food parcels?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry is busy with all his mail. He has opened six of his letters and is now working on the last. Stosh comes into SHOT and peeks over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do those broads say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do they always say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I wanna hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hiding the letters) It's not good for you, Animal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stosh grabs one of the letters from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! This is with a typewriter! It's  from a finance company!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it is from the finance company.  So it's better than no letter at  all. So they want the third payment  on the Plymouth. (showing him five  more letters) So they want the fourth, the fifth,  the sixth and the seventh. So they  want the Plymouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sugar-lips Shapiro! Frightening,  ain't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding up the last  letter) This is a good one! (mounts a stool) Shut up, everybody! Listen to this! (he reads) 'The President of the United States  to Harry Shapiro. Greeting: Having  submitted yourself to a local board,  you are hereby notified to report...'  What do you know! So now I'm a draft  evader!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hoffy is walking across the muddy compound towards the  barrack, leading a couple of new prisoners: LIEUTENANT DU and SERGEANT BAGRADIAN. They are exhausted but, by contra to the old P.O.W.s, remarkably clean. They are followed b P.O.W., carrying two barrack bags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (opening door to  barrack) This is it, gentlemen. Don't bother  to scrape your shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leads them into the barrack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hoffy leads in Dunbar, Bagradian and the P.O.W. with the  barrack bags. He snaps the line, the wash jiggles through the barrack. Everybody turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, gang! Meet our new guests.  This is Lieutenant Dunbar and this  is Sergeant Bagradian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole barracks comes to its feet and salutes him with mock reverence. Harry dashes up and polishes with his sle the Lieutenant's bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knock it off, boys. The pleasure's  all mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lieutenant will be with us for a  week or so until the Krauts can ship  him to the officers' camp in Silesia.  Looks like all the railroad lines  out of Frankfurt are fouled up because  somebody blew up an ammunition train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody, my eye. (indicating Dunbar) The Lieutenant did it -- right in  the station -- with fifty German  guards around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (climbing off the  stool) Well! Glad to have you with the  organization!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're just in time for the Christmas  Pageant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks more like the lost company of  Tobacco Road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating Bagradian) He's an actor. You should see him do  imitations. He can imitate anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he can imitate a girl, he's made.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey -- do Lionel Barrymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do Grable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it, boys. They were shot down  two days ago and they've been on  their feet ever since. (to Stosh and Harry) Fix them some tea, will you? (to Dunbar and  Bagradian) Price will show you your bunks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price leads them towards the bunks which were formerly  occupied by Manfredi and Johnson, the P.O.W. with the bar bags following them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had a couple of unexpected  vacancies. Which one will it be --  the upper or lower, Lieutenant Dunbar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cookie is just finished shaving Sefton. Sefton turns in h chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Dunbar? It wouldn't be  James Schuyler Dunbar? From Boston?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it would. Do we know each other?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating Sefton) He's from Boston, too. But you  wouldn't know him, not unless you  had your house robbed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sefton gets up, wiping the soap off his ears with the tow

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he would. We applied for  Officers' Training together, remember?  They turned me down, but I'm glad to  see you made it. Of course, it  couldn't be that all that dough behind  you had something to do with it! (to the others) His mother's got twenty million  dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've got a summer house in  Nantucket, with an upstairs polo  field. (to Price) You better put a canopy over his  bunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lay off, Sefton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Dunbar) With your mother's pull, how come  you're not a chicken colonel by now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lay off, I said -- if you don't want  your head handed to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from the table) Tea is being served on the verandah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry sets two chow cans on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Stosh) Where are the napkins, Animal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stosh tears off two sheets of toilet paper from a roll,  separates them and puts them next to the chow cans. By no Dunbar and Bagradian come over to the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Dunbar, a la Ronald  Colman) Do be seated, Bonita. What a perfectly  charming table arrangement. They  must have copied it from House  Beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stosh starts pouring hot water from the pot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Animal! How many times have I told  you, you got to pour from the left!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stosh reverses his direction. Harry has taken a faded tea bag out of his watch pocket. He dunks it three times into each chow can. Then, looking at the tea bag as if it were watch:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dinner will be served at seven sharp.  Black tie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts the tea bag back into his watch pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd they get you, Lieutenant?  Over Frankfurt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the Schweinfurt run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many ships did you lose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half the group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flying out of England?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Paddington, 92nd Bomber Group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wide-eyed) Hey, Lieutenant. How did you blow up  that train with fifty guards around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just lucky, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't let him kid you. Cagney couldn't  have pulled a sweeter job. (a la Cagney) All right, boys. We were waiting in  the depot in Frankfurt, see? And  there was an ammunition train coming  through, the longest ammunition train  you ever saw, see? So Dunbar gets  himself in the men's room, see? Fixes  himself a time bomb, busts open the  window and just as the train moves  out, lays the thing in there, see?  So then, he comes out like nothing's  happened and three minutes later you  can hear it -- boom! Broke every  window in Frankfurt. It was gorgeous!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't talk about things like  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (himself again) They never caught on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They may. That's why I would keep my  mouth shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're all Americans here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Krauts have a way of getting  information.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Especially in this barrack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what we'd like to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sefton is just putting on his leather jacket. He has been listening to what has been going on. Cookie hands him out the footlocker a bottle of Rhine wine and a carton of  cigarettes. Sefton tucks them inside his leather jacket.  Cookie now hands him a pair of silk stockings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a low voice) There's only one pair left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting the stockings  in his pocket) We'll get some more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts his cap on and walks toward the door. As he passe the others:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where does a guy take a hot shower  around here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hot showers? Dig him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. No hot showers. You wash in  the latrine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Latrine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stopping in his tracks) What did you expect, glamor boy? The  Officers' Club with a steam room and  a massage maybe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going after him) Just a minute. You made a couple of  cracks before and I let them slide.  But I don't intend to take any more.  If you resent my having money, start  a revolution, but get off my back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Lieutenant. All your dough  won't help you here. Because here  you're on your own. And no mother to  throw you a lifebelt. Now let's see  how good you can swim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has picked a little twig off the Christmas tree. He pu it in his buttonhole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, boys, but my taxi's waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plenty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Number one on the rat parade!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hoffy nods to Duke. Duke leaves the barrack, after Sefton

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the muddy compound there is a tag football game going with some forty G.I.s watching. Sefton is walking along. Behind him, Duke has come out of the barrack and is following him. Sefton becomes aware of it. Nonchalantly, he walks into a wash latrine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sefton comes in. There is another P.O.W. there, a colored guy, just finishing washing his hands. Sefton quickly cli up a couple of rungs of the ladder leading to the water t and stops there. The colored P.O.W. doesn't notice it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duke stands some distance away, watching the only pair of legs visible under the raised partition. The legs move no down the length of the latrine and out the other end. The colored P.O.W. emerges and walks off with his back toward Duke. Duke follows him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sefton jumps off the ladder and exits the way he came in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a funny thing about Sefton  and me. I guess I knew him as well  as anybody else in the camp because  I had worked for him for two years.  But there were lots of things I didn't  know about him. Take for instance,  where he would disappear to once in  a while. Of course, I had a hunch,  but it seemed so crazy I couldn't  quite believe it -- Just as I would  never have believed that Sefton was  the guy that would give away  Lieutenant Dunbar for blowing up  that ammunition train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duke is still following the wrong guy. Now the P.O.W. sto to talk to a pal. Duke realizes his mistake. He dashes ba into the wash latrine and comes out again. He stands ther frustrated. With the football players rushing about, pass being thrown and G.I.s milling around, he has lost Sefton

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: START on the electric light -- the cord is again tied up  into a noose. CAMERA PANS to Harry. He is made up a la Hitler; his hair combed across his forehead and a charcoal mustache on his lip. He is now making up Joey as Hitler, with two fingers blackened in charcoal. Joey just sits in his bunk, dumbly At the table, Hoffy is playing gin with Dunbar. Price  kibitzing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Harry) Cut the horseplay, Harry. What's the  matter with you guys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And don't blame me if you all wind  up in the cooler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's two?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lays down his hand. Stosh, at the door, holds it slightly ajar and peeks out  into the compound. He too is made up as Hitler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get ready! Here he comes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He SLAMS the door, snaps wash line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A German truck draws up, loaded with blankets. Schulz, si next to the driver, gets out and starts into the barrack. Two German guards stay behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schulz enters, closes the door behind him. From OFF comes Bagradian's voice: A double-talk German gibberish in the  characteristic guttural sounds of der Fuehrer. Schulz stops, mystified. Bagradian stands on a stool giving a lecture to some thir P.O.W.s, all of them with their backs towards Schulz.  Bagradian's face cannot be seen as he holds the Mein Kamp book in front of it. Schulz listens for a little while to Bagradian's ranting and raving. Then he stamps his foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen! Gentlemen! Attention!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bagradian lowers the book. He too is made up as Hitler. H raises his arm in the Nazi salute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heil, Hitler!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (responding  automatically) Heil, Hitler!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He catches himself, lowers the arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (jovially) Droppen Sie dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a la Hitler) Quiet! We are indoctrinating! (to the others) Is you all indoctrinated?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in unison) Jawohl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is you all good Nazis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jawohl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is you all little Adolfs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jawohl!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we shall all zalute Feldwebel  von und zu Schulz! About face!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The P.O.W.s wheel around and face Schulz. They are all ma up as Hitler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sieg heil! Sieg heil! Sieg Heil!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After each 'Sieg heil' they raise their arms in salute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ach! One Fuehrer is enough! Now  please, gentlemen! Take off the  mustaches immediately. Or do you  want me arrested by the Gestapo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jawohl!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You would be very sorry to get a new  Feldwebel. Somebody without a sense  of humor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, boys. Wipe off the mustaches.  Now what is it, Schulz?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men start wiping off the mustaches and straightening  their hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, tomorrow morning the Geneva  Man is coming to inspect the camp  whether we are living up to the  International Convention. I am sure  he will find we are treating you  very well. You must not run around  in your underwear. And take off the  wash. The Kommandant wants all the  barracks to be spic and also span.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll put pink ribbons on the bedbugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kommandant also sends you clean  blankets. He wants every man to have  a new, clean blanket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We know! We got them last year. Five  minutes after the Geneva Man was  gone, the blankets were gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One more thing, gentlemen. The  Kommandant told me to pick up the  radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What radio?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The one you are hiding in the barrack,  don't you know? The one your friend  without the leg is smuggling all  over the compound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schulz, you're off your nut!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have no radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, gentlemen, I will find it  myself. Now let's see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts wandering around the barrack, drawing closer an closer to the trick bucket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I cold? Am I getting warmer? Hot,  maybe? Very hot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has reached the bucket. With his boot he kicks it over the floor. The water spills on Cookie's shoes. The radio the earphones lie on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picking up radio) What is this? This is water?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a mouse trap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding up earphones) And this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My grandmother's ear-muffs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Dunbar) Look at them, Lieutenant. Everybody  is a clown! How do you expect to win  the war with an army of clowns?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We sort of hope you'll laugh  yourselves to death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schulz gives out with a big phony laugh. As he laughs his eyes fall on: The light bulb and the cord tied up in a noose. Schulz stops laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, outside everybody, for the  blankets! Everybody out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He herds them out. Joey is in his bunk, still wearing the Hitler mustache.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside! You, too!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes Joey out. Alone in the barrack again, Schulz qu walks to the table, exchanges the black queens and straig out the light cord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men, standing in line are being issued new blankets b the two German guards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That Schulz pig. I'll get him yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hold him. I'll slug him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not Schulz. It's that stoolie.  Whoever he is, he's sure batting a  thousand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guy I want to talk to is Sefton.  Where's Sefton? (turns to Cookie, who  is coming up in the  line) You haven't seen Sefton, have you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frightened) No, I haven't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hurrying them along) Der Naechste!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The P.O.W.s are coming back with the blankets. Schulz is  standing at the door with radio and earphones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out to the  guards) Henkel! Krause! (to Hoffy) I'm very sorry about the mouse trap,  but the war news are very depressing  anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two German guards have entered. Schulz points at the  rolled-up volley ball net under one of the bunks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might as well also confiscate the  antenna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guards carry out the wire-roll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: American know-how!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simultaneously, he snaps the wash line. Shaking with laug he exits. As he goes out, Cookie squeezes himself into th barrack, carrying his blanket. He starts edging towards h bunk, but Hoffy grabs him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Cookie, let's hear it:  where is Sefton?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I told you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wouldn't be at the Kommandant's,  would he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did they trade him for the radio?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During this, they have backed him up towards his bunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't we just look in those  footlockers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, you little stooge. Hand  over them keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't got any keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Then I'll get me a key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs off a piece of iron holding up a corner of the  distillery. Meanwhile, Harry has pulled out Sefton's  footlockers. Stosh shoves the iron bar into one of the lo Stops. Looks up at Hoffy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Hoffy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stosh starts ripping off the lock. Cookie has shrunk back into the corner of his bunk. The first footlocker is cracked open. It is brimful of  cigarettes, chocolate bars, coffee, tea and sugar. Stosh pries open the second footlocker. He throws back the top: there is a dazzling assortment of cameras, binoculars,  wristwatches, beer steins, bottles of Rhine wine and a cu clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of all the hoarding cruds!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like Macey's basement, don't  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That kid's richer than my mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry has picked up the cuckoo clock. It opens, the birdi emerges and cuckoos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slaps the door shut on it. Stosh pulls from under the  binoculars a pair of silk stockings. He holds them up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For cryin' out loud! What would he  be doing with these?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suppose you ask me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They turn. In the door stands Duke, breathless. He had ju come in from the Compound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, ask me! Because I got the  goods on Mister Sefton. Because this  time he didn't shake me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves toward the telescope at the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a look for yourself. It'll curdle  your guts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He swings the telescope around so it faces the Russian  Compound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Russian women!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all dash towards the window and the telescope. Hoffy pushes through and looks himself, focusing the telescope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try the end barrack. Where the goodies  are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hoffy looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatiently) Come on, Hoffy! We all want to see!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hoffy straightens up. Stosh pushes Harry away and looks  through the telescope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Duke) How did he get over there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy! Walked right through the gate,  past the guard. Like he was some  Kraut Field Marshal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stosh, looking through the telescope, has let go with a l whistle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is murder!

dialogues.speaker: RUSSIAN BARRACK
dialogues.text: The telescope is focused on the window, revealing: A party is in progress. Sefton is the only man among some eight Russian women. He lies on a bunk, reclining like a  Sultan. The Russian women around him vie for his favor. O plays the balalaika. Another is dancing the Kazatski on t table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men struggle to get at the telescope. Harry jerks Sto away. Meanwhile, Blondie moves in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling Blondie off) Go play with your marbles!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stinkin' miser! Keeping all that  to himself!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would I like to lay my hands on him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from the telescope) Who wants to lay their hands on him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blondie, Bagradian and a couple others have dashed to the footlocker, grabbed themselves some binoculars, and dash  back to the window to look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Hoffy and Price) So I'm a vigilante, huh? So what are  the Barrack Officers going to do  now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry Duke. We'll handle it  from here on in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better handle it fast. Before a  few more of us get knocked off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hoffy, boiling mad, grabs the telescope from the guys and flings it across the room. The telescope smashes against Sefton's bunk. It almost hi Cookie. He cringes back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sefton is coming back from the Russian compound. There ar about a dozen P.O.W.s about. He pauses at the gate until couple of P.O.W.s have moved on. Then he walks through th gate, giving the German guard a little high sign. Whistli a Russian tune, Sefton crosses toward Barrack 4.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The electric lights are burning. Sefton enters, whistling Duke slips behind him, slams the door shut, and stands th blocking the exit. Sefton stops whistling. He surveys the situation. About t five P.O.W.s stand around silently, looking at him. Hoffy Price, Harry and Stosh in the foreground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (casually) Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too late for chow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter, boys? Is my slip  showing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll say it is. You spilled a little  borscht on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Borscht?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a nice time over there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! Somebody was peeking!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nonchalantly starts peeling off his coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah! Had a dreamy time! Those dames,  they really know how to throw a party.  I've handled some pretty interesting  material in my day, but between you  and me, there's just nothing like  the hot breath of the Cossacks.  There's a couple of blonde snipers  over there, real man-killers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He breaks off as his eyes fall on his footlockers. He see that they have been broken open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They just look at him. He turns to Cookie, who is curled in his bunk, petrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened, Cookie? Who did it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We did it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There better not be anything missing.  This is private property.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So was the radio private property.  So was Manfredi and Johnson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the radio?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moving in on Sefton) Yeah, what about it? (to Hoffy and Price) Cut the horsing around. We know he's  the stoolie and we know what the pay- off is. Let's get on with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get on with what? What is this  anyway? A Kangaroo Court? Why don't  you get a rope and do it right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You make my mouth water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're all wire happy, boys. You've  been in this camp too long. You put  two and two together and it comes  out four. Only it ain't four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's it add up to you, Sefton?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It adds up that you got yourselves  the wrong guy. Because I'm telling  you. The Krauts wouldn't plant two  stoolies in one barrack. And whatever  you do to me you're going to have to  do all over again when you find the  right guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from the window) Watch it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He snaps the wash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Planks have been laid from the Administration Building to Barrack 4. Two German guards are just putting down the la plank right against the barrack. Von Scherbach strides do the planks. He is accompanied by his aide and two German  soldiers. They, of course, are marching through the mud. aide hurries ahead to open the door to the barrack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Von Scherbach enters, followed by his aide. All the P.O.W look on tensely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, Sergeants. (looking around) A bit dank in here, isn't it?...  Where is the Baracken-Fuehrer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stepping up) Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a Lieutenant here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds out his hand. His aide hands him a slip of paper

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) ...a Lieutenant James Dunbar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am Lieutenant Dunbar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is your number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading off his dog- tags) 105-353.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checking with paper) That is correct. (he salutes) Lieutenant Dunbar, I came to apologize  for the accommodations. Ordinarily,  of course, we never put officers up  with enlisted men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite a transportation jam we are  having outside of Frankfurt! They  are very angry in Berlin. They will  be even angrier on the East Front,  waiting for that ammunition train.  Don't you think so, Lieutenant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you're talking  about, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you don't. Now, Lieutenant,  how would you like to join me in my  quarters? I have a nice fire going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm okay here. Why bother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No bother. I'm very grateful for a  little company. You see, I suffer  from insomnia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever try forty sleeping pills?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to his aide, sharply) Abfuehren!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The aide takes Dunbar by the arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the aide) Wait a minute. We have some rights  here. (to von Scherbach) Why is this man being taken out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking around the  room) Curtains would do wonders for this  barrack. (on second thought) You will not get them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He snaps his fingers. The aide marches Dunbar out. Von  Scherbach follows, slamming the door after him. For a moment, there is a stunned silence. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did he ever find out about that  ammunition train?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must have shot off your mouth  all the way from Frankfurt to here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We did not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe just a hint or so. Think hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have to think. We didn't  tell anything to anybody. Not a word.  Not until we hit this barrack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men stand struck. Then all eyes go to Sefton. He is closing his footlockers He senses their look. Straightens up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you looking at me for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer. He shoves the footlockers under his bunk. From OFF come whistles and shouts: 'Lights Out!' The lights go out. The barrack is in semi-darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose some jerk's going to say I  did it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crawls into his bunk. He lies there, his eyes wide ope The air is charged. After a long moment, the men move in on him, led by Duke Stosh. Sefton sits up to meet them. A couple of guys grab him from behind, hold him down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you try it one at a time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first blows are falling. Joey lies in his bunk, his head propped against the bedpo his face still in idiotic Hitler make-up. He does not  comprehend the SOUNDS from Sefton's bunk, the beating and muffled cries. In the foreground, the electric bulb, hang straight, sways gently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wintry day. Cold sun shining. Through the big gate two  vehicles are driving into the compound: a 1939 Buick seda and a tarpaulin-covered truck. The vehicles are muddy,  battered, and carry the insignia of the Red Cross. They s in front of the Administration Building. P.O.W.s converge from all sides. Out of the Buick steps the Geneva Man: a  friendly type, about fifty-five, dressed in civilian clot and carrying a brief case. He tips his Homburg to the P.O but they are more interested in the truck. While a couple German lieutenants exchange credentials with the Geneva M the Red Cross drivers roll back the tarpaulin of the truc and the P.O.W.s (including all the men from Barrack 4, ex Sefton) crowd around the goodies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, there's a lot of folks around  these days that don't believe in  Santa Claus. I always did and I always  will. For a while there, I thought  the German Luftwaffe had shot him  down, reindeer, sleigh and all. But,  no sir! Come the day before Christmas,  he showed up with some presents for  us, the Geneva Man did. He had started  out with seven truckloads. He was  lucky to get one of them through --  with all the bombing and booby traps  and pilfering. Still, they were  presents and made you feel good:  coffee, a little sugar and some candy  and toothbrushes and about a thousand  rolls of that sanitary paper. Brother,  they sure kept sending us reams of  that stuff. I'll bet you if they had  dropped all that paper on Berlin the  first day, the war would have been  over right then and there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is quite changed now. The wash is gone. Everything is away. The barrack is apparently empty, except for a Germa guard and Schulz, who gives the place a last once-over. T German guard is sweeping dust under the bunks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schnell! Schnell! Bevor der Mann vom  Roten Kreuz inspizieren kommt!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At one of the bunks he sees a miserable plant, potted in smelly old shoe. He picks it up and gives it to the guard

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nehmen Sie das hinaus!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guard takes the shoe out. Schulz, about to leave hims sees a pair of socks hanging from the line above. He rips them down and tucks them disgustedly under a blanket. Fro OFF comes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Schulz!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schulz turns. At the other end of the barrack, Sefton is lying in his b He has propped himself up on his elbow. His face is batte One eye is swollen, one ear gashed. His body is aching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crossing) What is this? You must get out of  the bunk. The Geneva Man is coming  to inspect the barrack!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees Sefton's condition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Du lieber Gott! How do you look? You  had a fight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding out a pair  of silk stockings) How would you like to give Frau Schulz  a pair of silk stockings for  Christmas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should go and see the doctor.  Maybe I can -- (breaking off) Silk stockings?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. Take them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He presses the stockings upon Schulz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wunderbar! Maybe they are too  wunderbar for my wife. But there is  a piano teacher in the village --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how about three hundred cigarettes  for yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has dragged himself out of his bunk and is taking cart of cigarettes out of the footlocker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three hundred cigarettes! What is it  you want from me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's the guy, Schulz?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The one you work with. Who is he?  How do you do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not want those cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, you do!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls himself up with an armful of cartons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll make it five hundred!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sefton grabs him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd better talk, Schulz, because  I'm going to find out with you or  without you. Because I won't let go  for a second. Because they'll have  to kill me to stop me. So talk!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talk what? I do not know anything!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many do you want? A thousand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bends over the footlocker, fighting his pain, comes up with more cartons. He thrusts them upon Schulz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it! Take it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a SOUND of P.O.W.s entering. Schulz looks off. The P.O.W.s are coming back from the compound with the  Christmas presents. Hoffy, Price, Duke, Harry and Stosh s in the door, looking at Sefton and Schulz. Schulz quickly drops the cartons on Sefton's bunk. Stands embarrassed for a moment, then retrieves his poise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen! When the Geneva Man comes  through the barrack, I don't want  any funny business. No mustaches. We  will all behave ourselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes toward the other end of the barrack, which is by filled with all the other P.O.W.s. Schulz stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And gentlemen! You will not complain  to the Geneva Man. Because I have  orders from the Kommandant to report  everyone who complains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men move toward Sefton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at him! Dunbar's being crucified  and he's trading again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you get enough last night?  You itching for more?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some guys never learn!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I called a meeting of the barrack  chiefs this morning, Sefton. I thought  maybe I could get you transferred  into another barrack. It turns out  nobody likes you any more than we  do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're stuck with me, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe those Russian dames would take  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not with that kisser -- not any more!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cookie has come through the door with some ice in a towel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sefton) Here... put some ice on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duke grabs the ice-bag from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat it, stooge! (to Hoffy and Price) Go on -- tell the crumb where he  stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Sefton. You got away lucky  last night. One more move, no matter  how small, and you'll wake up with  your throat slit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard that, Sefton?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure I heard it. I still got one  good ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From OFF comes Schulz' WHISTLE. They look. Schulz stands at the far door, blowing his whistle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Achtung! Achtung! Everybody at  attention for the Geneva Man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men all come to attention before their bunks. The Ger lieutenant enters, ushering in the Geneva Man. Schulz sti and clicks his heels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you were, gentlemen. Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes off his hat, looks around, and as the scene  progresses, moves through the barrack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we have a typical barrack. It  houses seventy-five men. Every one  of them has his own bunk, naturally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naturally. It would be rather awkward  to have three men in one bunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As for the blankets, you will notice  they are very warm. Fifty percent  wool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They also smell of moth balls. (to a P.O.W. at that  particular bunk) When were they issued? This morning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The P.O.W. looks noncommittally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Lieutenant) What do you do for heat in this  barrack? No stove?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men here used it for a trap door,  so we had to remove it temporarily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long is temporarily? I trust not  until July.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the other door a couple of P.O.W.s have brought i the chow-tub, steaming with some brew. They put it on the table in the middle of the barrack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here you see a typical meal the  prisoners are getting. What are we  having today, Schulz?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bean soup with ham hocks. Would you  like to taste it? (fishing with the  ladle) Where's the ham hock? There should  be a ham hock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When he finds it, we'll send it to  Geneva.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Geneva Man continues down the barrack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are there any complaints? Please  speak up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks around. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be afraid to talk. That's what  the Geneva Convention is for: to  protect the rights of prisoners of  war. Whether they are Americans or  Germans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Harry) What have you got to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like it here. (then with a shrug) Aeh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Price) What about you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right. Considering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Geneva Man walks on. Stops at Sefton's bunk. Sees his battered face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to you? Were you beaten?  Why don't you answer? (to the German  Lieutenant) What did you do to this man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They didn't do nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who beat you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody beat me. We were playing  pinochle. It's a rough game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stepping up) Pardon me, sir. Since you want us to  speak up, there was a man removed  from this barrack last night. A  Lieutenant Dunbar. We sure would  appreciate your looking into it.  That's if they haven't shot him yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the German  Lieutenant) Why was the man arrested?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sabotage. He blew up a train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'd have to prove that first,  wouldn't they? Isn't that what the  Geneva Convention says? You can't  just take a man out and shoot him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The office is in the Administration Building. It is primi sparsely furnished. A desk with a couple of phones on it. Iron stove. A black leather sofa. Maps. In the room are von Scherbach, Dunbar and the Colonel's  ORDERLY. The Colonel's boots, shining gloriously, stand n the desk. He is pacing up and down in his stocking feet  talking to Dunbar. In his hand is the black queen from th chess game. He tosses it into the air once in a while and catches it. Dunbar stands close to a wall. He is complete exhausted, fighting sleep. START the SCENE on the chess piece in von Scherbach's han and PAN with it as von Scherbach walks to reveal the room

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have no idea how boring my life  here is. If it weren't for an  occasional air raid or some foolish  prisoners trying to escape, I wouldn't  know what to do. I want to thank you  for keeping me company. I don't drink,  I don't smoke, I don't read. I hate  music. That only leaves good  conversation. It will be a shame to  lose you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fighting sleep) I didn't do it -- I didn't do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you did! Twenty-six carloads  of munitions gone off like a trick  cigar! The S.S. is running around in  circles. The Gestapo is arresting  the wrong people. And von Scherbach  has caught the fish. Most amusing,  isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dunbar falls back against the wall, yawning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (straightening him up) You are being rude again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to sleep. Give me five minutes  on that couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at his  wristwatch) Nine-thirty. General von Pfeffinger  should be at his desk by now. Shall  we call Berlin and tell him the good  news?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wearily) I didn't do it. I didn't do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Von Scherbach has gone to the desk, picks up the phone an cranks it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hauptkommando Berlin. General von  Pfeffinger. Dringend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up, sits on the edge of the desk holding up his  stocking feet. During his subsequent spiel, the orderly s up and pulls von Scherbach's boots on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you appreciate this moment,  Lieutenant. You see, I am a cavalry  man. All the von Scherbachs were  cavalry men. Well, you know what  happened to the cavalry. The young  ones they put into panzer divisions.  The older ones they put in the  quartermaster's corps. Or they made  them recruiting officers or wardens.  Like me. Wet nurses to putrid  prisoners. In Berlin they have  forgotten that Colonel von Scherbach  even exists. They will remember now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boots are on. The telephone RINGS. He jumps to his fe picks up the receiver, automatically clicks his heels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Berlin? Hier Oberst von Scherbach.  General von Pfeffinger? (clicks his heels) Oberst von Scherbach. Stalag 17.  Melde gehorchsamst haben als  Gefangenen den Mann, der Munitionszug  in Frankfurt in die Luft gesprengt  hat. Jawohl, Herr General -- (clicks the heels) -- Name Leutenant Dunbar. Sabotage.  Jawohl, Herr General.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He clicks his heels again, hangs up. Sits again on the de and the orderly automatically starts to pull off his boot

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There will be two S.S. men here  tomorrow to take you to Berlin. You  will be interrogated by the General  Staff. When you come to the part  about your arrest, I'm sure you won't  forget to give me the proper credit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sinking back) I want to sleep... I haven't slept  for three days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling him up) You will remember the name? Von  Scherbach? VON SCHER-BACH!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a KNOCK on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herein!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schulz opens the door, clicks his heels, salutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Der Mann vom Roten Kreuz moechte den  Herrn Oberst sprechen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ich bitte!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schulz ushers in the Geneva Man, steps out himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Herr Inspector! How did you  find the camp? Crowded but gemuetlich,  shall we say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to talk about Lieutenant  Dunbar. Is this Lieutenant Dunbar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What exactly is he charged with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever it is, it's out of your  jurisdiction. This man is not a  prisoner of war. Not any more. He is  a saboteur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is a prisoner of war until you  can prove sabotage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't do it. I was in the Frankfurt  station and the train was three miles  away when it blew up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, come now! You threw a time bomb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could I have had a time bomb?  They searched me when they took me  prisoner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the way you search your prisoners,  it does sound rather unlikely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I know is he did it. I am  satisfied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not. According to the Geneva  Convention --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there anything about letting a  guy sleep in the Geneva Convention?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has shuffled over to the sofa, and plunks himself down instantly asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Geneva Man) You were saying --?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simply this. After the hostilities  are ended, there will be such a thing  as a War Crimes Commission. If this  man should be convicted without proper  proof, you will be held responsible,  Colonel von Scherbach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Geneva Man looks straight into von Scherbach's eyes. Scherbach doesn't like the look. He picks up the black qu and tosses it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well. If you insist on details.  I have ways of finding out about  that blasted time bomb. Good day,  sir. (indicating stocking  feet) You will forgive me for receiving  you like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfectly all right. I do not like  boots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Geneva Man exits --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schulz!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schulz enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wie ist es moeglich dass dieser  Amerikaner eine Bombe bei sich hatte?  Er wurde doch bei der Gefangennahme  untersucht.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jawohl, Herr Kommandant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finden Sie es heraus -- und zwar  sofort!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zu Befehl, Herr Kommandant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Von Scherbach tosses him the black queen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: START ON black queen now with the other chess pieces on t table. PAN UP to disclose the barrack and the electric li its cord now looped. Sefton is lying in his bunk, dressed. Cookie above him in his bunk. At the center table, Harry, Stosh, Blondie and  Bagradian are decorating the Christmas tree with their do and hand-made candles. Joey sits there watching them. Blo takes off Joey's dogtags and puts them on the tree. One o the P.O.W.s is WHISTLING Silent Night. Sitting on a stool is Triz. He is knitting a little baby' garment. He pauses as a thought disturbs him, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe it. I believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes on with the knitting. Through the door come Duke and Price, followed by two P.O from another barrack. One P.O.W. is carrying an old-fashi phonograph, the other some records.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating center  table) Put it down, boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, -- music!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We made a deal with Barrack One.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Price) Any news on Dunbar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's still in the Kommandant's office.  That's all I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The P.O.W.s from Barrack One have deposited the phonograp and the records on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They follow him to Sefton's bunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Cookie) Let's have that distillery. Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cookie looks down at Sefton for permission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you looking at him for? (to Sefton) Any objections, Sefton?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The P.O.W.s climb on Sefton's bunk and start taking down distillery, which is piled up in Cookie's bunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sefton) Next we're going to auction off your  department store -- and your stable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the table, Price finishes cranking the machine. Harry  puts on a record and Price starts it playing. The tune is When Johnny Comes Marching Home. The guys start crowding  around. Meanwhile, Stosh has been watching the P.O.W.s from Barra One take down the distillery. As they start out, he grabs an empty glass jar, follows them surreptitiously and, in  moving, siphons off a stream of booze into the glass jar. One of the P.O.W.s catches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slapping his hand) Hey! That goes with it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pull the hose out of the glass jar and leave. Stosh, however, has gotten himself a pint of Schnapps. At the table Harry and a few others start singing with th record. Everybody has gathered around except Sefton and  Cookie. Price moves over to his bunk, (PAN with him). As takes off his jacket his eyes fall on -- The loop in the electric cord. Price. His eyes narrow for a split second. Then he takes cap off, cases the situation. The P.O.W.s are at the  phonograph. Sefton lies in his bunk, his eyes toward the  wall. Cookie climbs down to join the others. Nonchalantly Price crosses toward the lamp. He stands at the table wit his back towards the barrack. Picks up the black queen, p the top off, palms a small piece of paper, puts the top b and places the chess piece back on the chess board. He is about to read, but -- Some of the P.O.W.s come marching d the barrack toward Price in a take-off of a homecoming pa led by Harry and Stosh. Price stands there, the note in his fist. After they have passed, he opens his hand, reads the palmed note, puts it his pocket. He looks after the others who are now marchin down at the other end of the barrack. Casually, he pulls slip noose out of the light cord, and walks toward the ce table. Sefton, lying in his bunk, sees the shadow of the bulb an the light cord on the wall, swinging gently back and fort It doesn't make too much of an impression on him. However he definitely notices it and looks around for the cause. dismisses it and lies back in his bunk. The Johnny Comes Marching Home number is over and Bagradi now goes into an impersonation of Lionel Barrymore, as th mayor of a small town, welcoming home the returning warri and Jimmy Stewart answering for the soldiers. (To be work out later). During this, Price has joined them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do Bogart. Do Cary Grant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do Cagney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw! Do Grable!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes into a short impersonation of Clark Gable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grable, not Gable!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do Jimmy Durante!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do Cagney. Like you did yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a la Cagney) There was that ammunition train in  the depot at Frankfurt, see? So Dunbar  gets himself in the men's room and  fixes a time bomb, see? Then he waits  until the train starts moving out,  see? And one of the cars got the  door open with some straw on the  floor, see? So he throws it, see,  and three minutes later -- voom!  See?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Throws what? How could he have a  time bomb?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just pulled the old match gag, see!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the match gag?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take some matches, see? (takes a book of  matches from his  pocket) And a cigarette, see? (takes a burning  cigarette from Triz'  mouth) Tuck the cigarette in like this,  see? (tucks the cigarette  inside cover of match- book with the lit  end sticking out) Now the cigarette keeps burning like  a fuse, see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, that's a dandy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as it sinks in) Yeah. Pretty clever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do Grable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, here's Esther Williams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bends his head over and taps his ear, as if to shake o water. No laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do Cary Grant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bagradian goes into a take-off on Cary Grant. Price leans his head against a bunk-post, completely relaxed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights are on. In the foreground, our bulb, with a lo in the cord again. A Christmas party is in progress. On t center table, the pitiful little tree is lit. All the P.O in the barrack are huddled around the table, most of them sitting on the bunks. They are singing Adeste Fideles. It bitter cold. Outside the wind is howling. They are wrappe in blankets and most of them wear gloves. As for Sefton, he is lying in his bunk, a pariah. Duke co over from the group, pulls Sefton's foot-locker out and s taking out the bottles of Rhine wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the corkscrew?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He finds it, puts it in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a cigar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a cigar, puts it in his mouth and goes off with wine. As Sefton looks after him, his eyes are caught by t light cord and the noose in it. He stares at it. The P.O.W.s around the tree are SINGING, Price prominentl in the foreground. Duke has come with the wine and starts opening it. Stosh nudges Joey who sits next to him and po to a lone little package under the tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Joey -- there's a present for  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey doesn't move. Stosh picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want me to open it for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens it. It's the crude ocarina he carved out of wood Joey's eyes flicker. He takes the ocarina and starts play weird SOUNDS on it. The boys look at him, delighted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There, Joey -- ain't that better  than being a lawyer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nudging Stosh) Animal! Got a little something for  you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He produces from behind his back a package, wrapped with  ersatz ribbon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got a little something for you, too!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes out a package from inside his blanket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll open mine now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll open mine, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start opening their presents. It becomes apparent th each has given the other a roll of sanitary paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (throwing their arms  around each other) You're a doll! Just what I wanted!  How did you know!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the compound, a SIREN is heard. And shouts, Lights O The singing stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Air raid warning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not Christmas Eve!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wearily) Come on, everybody. Let's get out.  Let's hit those slit trenches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting up) I'm not really built for war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They blow out the candles. Simultaneously, the lights are turned off. The men start rushing out. Outside, through t door, men from other barracks can be seen hurrying by. Sefton sits up in his bunk, looking at the electric cord. The bulb is dark now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out, out everybody!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sefton looks off. Schulz has come through the door and is herding them out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must get out. For your own good,  you must get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, everybody! (pushing Joey) Let's go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schulz has come up to Sefton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter with you? You want  to be killed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not particularly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up his leather jacket and moves toward the door  where the other P.O.W.s are crowding out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Stosh and Harry  who are lingering  behind) Must you always be the last?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah? You jump in those trenches  first and everybody jumps on top of  you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you think I got my hernia?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price pushes them out. Dawdles at the door, closes it fro inside. He is alone with Schulz in the dark barrack. Schulz has gone over to the chess board, has picked up th black queen, opened it. There is no message. Price comes to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nun? Was ist? Haben Sie's  herausgefunden?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ich weiss alles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wie hat er's gemacht?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ganz einfach... Streichhoelzer...  und eine Zigarette...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a book of matches and puts a lighted cigarette i it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Passen Sie auf!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The "time bomb" goes off, lighting up their faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ach so!... ACH SO!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
